          performance.mark('gtm.start');
          (function (w, d, s, l, i) {
            w[l] = w[l] || [];
            w[l].push({ 'gtm.start': new Date().getTime(), event: 'gtm.js' });
            var f = d.getElementsByTagName(s)[0],
                j = d.createElement(s),
                dl = l != 'dataLayer' ? '&l=' + l : '';
            j.async = true;
            j.src = 'https://www.googletagmanager.com/gtm.js?id=' + i + dl;
            j.onload = function () {
              performance.mark('gtm.end');
              performance.measure('gtm', 'gtm.start', 'gtm.end');
            };
            f.parentNode.insertBefore(j, f);
        })(window, document, 'script', 'dataLayer', 'GTM-M36RG8PT');
        </script><head><meta charSet="utf-8"/><meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width"/><link rel="shortcut icon" href="https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/favicon.7bc3d920.ico"/><script>
      try {
        window.eventsToSend = window.eventsToSend || []
        window.eventsToSend.push({
          name: "page_rendering",
          timestamp: new Date().toISOString(),
          value: JSON.stringify({
            time: performance?.now()
          })
        })
      } catch (error) {
        console.error("Failed to push page render event:", error)
      }

Billy Leonard </h1><div class="stats Stats_root__p_BoZ"><span class="text Text_root__RtCPC Text_medium__TH6gG Text_secondary__o6d_E Likes_root__WVQ1_" style="-webkit-line-clamp:0" tabindex="0">1 <!-- -->views</span><button type="button" class="ai-tag unstyled-button AITag_tag__Xx37c" data-cy="ai-tag" aria-describedby="aiTag-description" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R2k97d6:" loading="lazy" decoding="sync"/></div><span>BlueHat Security Conference</span></a></div><div class="description Description_root__kt4uq Description_clamped__PaV_1"><div class="Description_wrapper__hYE9_"><p data-cy="document-description">The document presents a comprehensive analysis of targeted credential phishing threats over the past decade, detailing the evolution of attack methods and defenses. It highlights crucial developments like SMS interception, two-factor authentication vulnerabilities, and the importance of security keys and OAuth. The report outlines various actors involved in these attacks and suggests enhanced protective measures to combat ongoing threats.</p><div class="pills-list PillsList_root__2EydN"><a class="Pill_root__IqOYH" aria-label="View the featured presentations, documents and infographics in the Technology Category" href="https://www.slideshare.net/category/technology"><span class="icon data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-0" alt="Threat Analysis Group
November 2017 - @billyleonard
10 Years of Targeted Credential Phishing

But first, ….

What we don&#x27;t see in targeted phishing.

The Middle Ages.
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" fetchpriority="auto" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/copyof10yearsoftargetedcredentialphishing-msftfinal-171209002251/85/BlueHat-v17-10-Years-of-Targeted-Credential-Phishing-Billy-Leonard-17-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/copyof10yearsoftargetedcredentialphishing-msftfinal-171209002251/85/BlueHat-v17-10-Years-of-Targeted-Credential-Phishing-Billy-Leonard-17-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/copyof10yearsoftargetedcredentialphishing-msftfinal-171209002251/75/BlueHat-v17-10-Years-of-Targeted-Credential-Phishing-Billy-Leonard-17-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/copyof10yearsoftargetedcredentialphishing-msftfinal-171209002251/85/BlueHat-v17-10-Years-of-Targeted-Credential-Phishing-Billy-Leonard-17-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide18" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:720 / 405" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-17" alt="Threat Analysis Group

Password Alert.

Present Day.

Old habits die hard.

Targeted Credential Phishing | Billy Leonard </h2><div><ul class="Transcript_list__faItj"><div><li>1. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" November </a> 2017 - @billyleonard
10 Years of Targeted Credential Phishing
 </li></div><div><li>2. <a class="Transcript_link__MLbGS" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/10-years-of-targeted-credential-phishing-billy-leonard/83684578#2">Threat Analysis Group

Threat Analysis Group

      // This script assumes the Osano script is synchronously loaded
      try {
        window.eventsToSend = window.eventsToSend || []
        if (window.Osano) {
          window.eventsToSend.push({
            name: "osano_loaded",
            timestamp: new Date().toISOString(),
            value: JSON.stringify({
              time: performance?.now()
            })
          })
        }
      } catch (error) {
        console.error("Failed to push Osano event:", error)

It defines a targeted attack as one where threat actors actively pursue and compromise a specific target's infrastructure while maintaining anonymity. Targeted attacks are considered such when attackers have a specific target in mind. The main goal is to infiltrate the target's network and steal information. These attacks are persistent, with attackers expending significant effort to ensure the attack continues beyond the initial infiltration. Motives include information theft, espionage, and sabotage. Various tools are used in targeted attacks, and targets can be individuals, organizations, or sectors like finance, telecom, or healthcare. Case studies of past targeted attacks are also presented.","tags":[],"url":"https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/targeted-attacks-62950126/62950126","userLogin":"expert4u","userName":"Rahul","viewCount":834},{"algorithmId":"3","displayTitle":"Inside Attacker: An Overview","isSavedByCurrentUser":false,"pageCount":20,"score":0.3456,"slideshowId":"80218218","sourceName":"cm_text","strippedTitle":"inside-attacker-an-overview","extension":"pdf","thumbnail":"https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/insideattacker-anoverview-170927140635-thumbnail.jpg?width=600\u0026height=600\u0026fit=bounds","description":"An insider attacker is defined as a current or former employee, contractor, or other trusted entity that has access to an organization's network, systems, or data and intentionally or unintentionally misuses that access. Insider attacks account for 30-50% of cybersecurity incidents according to various studies. Insider threats can be malicious, negligent, or accidental. They are challenging to detect and prevent because insiders have legitimate access that makes their harmful actions difficult to distinguish from regular job functions. Potential solutions include improving security visibility, using red and blue teams to test defenses, following security standards for development, and monitoring behaviors for anomalies using artificial intelligence. Over 5+ years, ShadyRAT compromised over 70 victims, maintaining persistence for an average of 9 months to steal data. Attackers used open-source intelligence to profile targets, then sent malicious emails to install remote access tools allowing command and control. Stolen data was encrypted and transferred over months without detection. Lessons are that simple attacks can be highly effective when combined with social engineering and long-term access. The report is based on scan data from over 85,000 applications assessed between April 2018 and March 2019. Key findings include: (1) Most security flaws are eventually fixed but fix times have remained consistent, (2) The likelihood of flaws being fixed decreases over time leading to growing \"security debt\", (3) Frequent scanning correlated with faster fix times and lower security debt indicating the benefits of DevSecOps practices.
